items.title: Police say UK train stabbing that wounded 10 people not a 'terrorist incident'
items.standfirst: UK police said Sunday two British nationals were arrested on suspicion of attempted murder following a mass stabbing on a train in eastern England in which 10 people were wounded. ‚ÄúAt this stage, there is nothing to suggest that this is a terrorist incident,‚Äù UK Transport Police superintendent John Loveless told reporters. Vedika Bahl reports the latest.
items.content: UK police said Sunday two British nationals were arrested on suspicion of attempted murder following a mass stabbing on a train in eastern England in which 10 people were wounded. ‚ÄúAt this stage, there is nothing to suggest that this is a terrorist incident,‚Äù UK Transport Police superintendent John Loveless told reporters. Vedika Bahl reports the latest.

items.title: What We Know So Far About The Doncaster-London Train Attack

items.content: Two people arrested, and the police say they believe the attack was not terror-related.

items.title: UK: Two Britis arrested for train stabbing, police say not terrorist incident
items.standfirst: Two suspects were arrested after a mass stabbing on a London-bound train late Saturday that left ten people hospitalized, nine of them with potentially life-threatening injuries. Armed officers, supported by police vehicles and numerous ambulances, surrounded the railway station in the rural town of Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire, after the alarm was raised and the train was brought to an emergency stop there. France24 correspondent B√©n√©dicte Paviot tells us the latest.
items.content: Two suspects were arrested after a mass stabbing on a London-bound train late Saturday that left ten people hospitalized, nine of them with potentially life-threatening injuries. Armed officers, supported by police vehicles and numerous ambulances, surrounded the railway station in the rural town of Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire, after the alarm was raised and the train was brought to an emergency stop there. France24 correspondent B√©n√©dicte Paviot tells us the latest.

items.title: UK train stabbings injure nine, police arrest two suspects
items.standfirst: Nine people sustained life-threatening injuries in a series of stabbings on a train near Cambridge in eastern England on Saturday, leading to the arrest of two men in what Prime Minister Keir Starmer described as an ‚Äúappalling incident.‚Äù British Transport Police said that counterterrorism officers are assisting in the investigation as authorities work to determine the full circumstances and motive behind the attack. Florent Marchais tell us more.
items.content: Nine people sustained life-threatening injuries in a series of stabbings on a train near Cambridge in eastern England on Saturday, leading to the arrest of two men in what Prime Minister Keir Starmer described as an ‚Äúappalling incident.‚Äù British Transport Police said that counterterrorism officers are assisting in the investigation as authorities work to determine the full circumstances and motive behind the attack. Florent Marchais tell us more.

clusters.title: Fears grow for thousands trapped in Sudan‚Äôs el-Fasher as few residents reach safety
clusters.neutral_headline: Fears Grow for Trapped People in Sudan's El-Fasher

items.title: Fears grow for thousands trapped in Sudan‚Äôs el-Fasher as few residents reach safety
items.standfirst: Only a few thousand Sudanese have reached the nearest camp for displaced people in the days since Sudan‚Äôs paramilitary forces seized el-Fasher city, raising fears over tens of thousands who might still be trapped as survivors described killings and other atrocities, an aid group said Sunday.
items.content: Only a few thousand Sudanese have reached the nearest camp for displaced people in the days since Sudan‚Äôs paramilitary forces seized el-Fasher city, raising fears over tens of thousands who might still be trapped as survivors described killings and other atrocities, an aid group said Sunday.

items.title: New horrors emerge after RSF taking of Sudan‚Äôs el-Fasher: An analysis by professor Srinivasan
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of people are still trapped in Sudan's El-Fasher five days after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) seized the city. Fleeing survivors said on Saturday that paramilitary fighters separated families and killed children in front of their parents, and fresh satellite images suggested mass killings were likely ongoing. Professor of International Politics and Fellow of King's College at Camrbidge, Sharath Srinivasan, gives his insights.
items.content: Tens of thousands of people are still trapped in Sudan's El-Fasher five days after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) seized the city. Fleeing survivors said on Saturday that paramilitary fighters separated families and killed children in front of their parents, and fresh satellite images suggested mass killings were likely ongoing. Professor of International Politics and Fellow of King's College at Camrbidge, Sharath Srinivasan, gives his insights.

items.title: CBS News poll: Americans increasingly worried about economy amid shutdown

Anthony Salvanto joins "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" to break down the latest CBS News poll.

items.content: The US president says his threat is over killings of Christians - though experts say there is no evidence they are disproportionately targeted.

items.title: Trump threatens to send US military into Nigeria, alleging mass killing of Christians
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Saturday threatened Nigeria with a possible military attack after accusing the country of allowing the killing of Christians by Islamists. clusters.title: Russia fires wave of drones and missiles at Ukraine: At least 6 killed

items.title: Russia fires wave of drones and missiles at Ukraine: At least 6 killed
items.standfirst: Russia launched a barrage of drones and missiles at Ukraine overnight, killing at least six people, including two children, and leaving tens of thousands without power, officials reported Sunday. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the attacks, which also injured a dozen others, saying they demonstrated Moscow‚Äôs intent to ‚Äúinflict harm‚Äù on civilians. Despite U.S. calls to end its nearly four-year invasion, Russia has continued both its ground offensive and renewed strikes on Ukraine‚Äôs energy infrastructure. Former Advisor to Ukraine's Defence Ministry, Yuriy Sak, gives his insights.

items.title: Russian blitz on Ukraine kills six people, including two children
items.standfirst: A wave of drones and missiles were fired into Ukraine by Russia overnight on Saturday and Sunday, killing at least six people including two boys aged 11 and 14. Russia's strikes on Ukraine's energy grid cut power to the entire eastern Donetsk region, as well as almost 58,000 households in the southern Zaporizhzhia region, Ukrainian officials said.
items.content: A wave of drones and missiles were fired into Ukraine by Russia overnight on Saturday and Sunday, killing at least six people including two boys aged 11 and 14. Russia's strikes on Ukraine's energy grid cut power to the entire eastern Donetsk region, as well as almost 58,000 households in the southern Zaporizhzhia region, Ukrainian officials said.

items.title: Ukraine deploys special forces to the eastern city of Pokrovsk after a Russian assault
items.standfirst: Ukraine on Saturday deployed special forces to the eastern city of Pokrovsk, which is under an intense Russian assault. The city has been in Moscow's sights for over a year and lies on a major supply route for the Ukrainian army. Russia's army fired 270 missiles over October, up 46 percent on the previous month, according to an AFP analysis. France24 correspondent Emmanuelle Chaze reports the latest from Kharkiv.
